title-group.article-title: Social decision-making and the brain: a comparative perspective

article-meta.aff: 1 Department of Neuroscience, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA
2 Montreal Neurological Institute, McGill University, Montréal, QC, Canada
3 Department of Psychology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA
4 Department of Marketing, Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA

abstract.p: The capacity and motivation to be social is a key component of the human adaptive behavioral repertoire. Recent research has identified social behaviors remarkably similar to our own in other animals, including empathy, consolation, cooperation and strategic deception. Moreover, neurobiological studies in humans, nonhuman primates and rodents have identified shared brain structures—the so-called "social brain"— apparently specialized to mediate such functions. Neuromodulators may regulate social interactions by "tuning" the social brain, with important implications for treating social impairments. Here we survey recent findings in social neuroscience from a comparative perspective, and conclude that the very social behaviors that make us human emerge from mechanisms shared widely with other animals as well as some that appear to be unique to humans and other primates.
